My 9 year old loves the orange chicken and teriyaki (sweet) chicken so if we are in the Mall and she is hungry I will indulge her.

I don't eat here.

Ick.

The good part?  The lady behind the counter is very kind.

A lady at my office used to call this place $h1tty Gardens and the name stuck.

I just have never had a great meal here.  Usually we've had take-out (they deliver) and I ate in the restaurant (which was loud, crowded and cefeteria like) one time.  NEVER will I return.  If you want GOOD cheap CHinese - go to A Mandarin Restaurant or Square on Square.

The dumplings were thick and doughy with greasy meat inside.  (Blech).  The Chicken & Brocolli was OK - not bad, actually.  The fried rice just seems old and over-soyed to me.

Not a fan.

3 stars is pretty generous - it's more live 2 or 2 and a quarter.
The dumplings are crispy and FRIED and the prices seem a mite high for essential fast food noodles.

The lady at the counter was icy cold toward me - and the place was essentially empty.

I would only go back here in a pinch as Bill M. has said.

OMG - I can't believe they've survived for all these years.  It's fruity-drink, frat boy, college chick central.

Not my kinda place - and never was.
Not great - and has declined steadily over the years.

I would never stay here.  Absolute mediocrity.  We attend events here and the event people pick this place for the (reasonable) price of conference space.

Yuck.

Depressing.

Please renovate and clean - bathrooms and public spaces, too!

Finally used my eversave (valid only during dinner - and I sure know why!)

Service was just awful - very cold female server worked her butt off - while other guy stood there (not wonder she's so angry).

The food was good.  "Happy Hour" small plates are $5 - I tried the "Fried Shrimp Joe" which was kinda like shrimp-toast filling deep-fried and cut into chunks.  Tasty - but so greasy - will not get that again.

Sliced beef with eggplant (and I added brocolli - no charge) for $16.50 was a HUGE portion (Took about 1/2 home) and the beef was tender and delicious.

Great food - but this place is a LUNCH SPOT - and is truly cursed at dinner (dine-in).
Dim lighting, borderline mean servers and just not fun.

Won;t be back so soon.
Meanwhile - for takeout I love the hot and sour soup here.
Again - they have GREAT food.
It's a shame my dinner "dine-in" was so MEH.

Very disappointed.  Came back to Pure Fare after being away for a couple of years.
My kid ordered a $7 Strawberry Banana Smoothie (Strawberries, 1 Banana and Ice for $7!!!!  Highway robbery) and the cup was not even all the way full.

Not comin' back.

Used to love it here.  So sad.

There are 3 - yes THREE Auntie Anne's in 30th Street Station.
The "main one" where they can bake pretzels is larger and back by the bar abd Surf City Squeeze.

There is a kiosk (they cart the pretzels over) on the concorse floor (near Amtrak) and another small store near the SEPTA area.

Like obese Philadelphians really need 3 of these?  Anyhow - it's not good for you - and while a hot cinnamon sugar pretzel (especially fresh and hot) tastes good to me, I nearly always feel ill afterward and regret the 470 cals.

Skip it.  Get some fruit or hummus from Old Nelson's.
Or better yet - leave the building and go get "real" food.

Yick.  First of all -it's take out only.  There are (maybe) 2 card tables on which to eat.

Mediocre pizza and OK hoagies.

If you work at the Mercer Museum or nearby, this is a decent enough lunch spot, but for "hoity-toity" Doylestowners there are much nicer choices.

The food here is just awful.

My (now) 11 year old, however loves the $2.99 bubble tea - and until we can find another place to get bubble tea (she is partial to honeydew) we get it here.

The young lads running the front counter are always kind to us.
Wish the food were better. I do not and will not eat here.
Sooooo dirty.  Eew!

Not a great Shoprite - but a little better than the one near the Target.
NO customer service at all - and lines were pretty long on the (Saturday - duh) day we were there.

We go to the (also yucky) SuperFresh on Columbus for our bi-monthly shopping trips and supplement with Farmer's Market Fruit & Veggies (in spring/summer) and Whole Foods or Trader Joe's for other things.

Oh - and Target.  We're there a few times a month also.

Pro:  This shoprite has a BIG parking lot and we found a space easily - even though the store was busy and lines were long.  (Hey - open an extre couple of registers on the weekends, OK?)

Absolutely horrendous service.
My husband, 7 year old and I stopped in for an early (5:45 ish) dinner on a Sunday.

Only a few tables occupied and 3 staffers seated in the back corner.
Several minutes passed before the cold, bitter hostess reluctantly got up to seat us.  Even my kid asked "Are we supposed to seat ourselves?".

We were given a table way in the back near the kitchen and eventually asked to be moved due to the loud banging and pounding (we could hear every aspect of the food prep.)

Meanwhile the food, once it arrived was surprisingly good - 4 star even - but due to the awful experience we won't be back - at least not for a long while.
The rosa sauce is great, but I can get it other places where the servers are kind and attentive.

Yuck.  I don't really like fast food anyway - and Wendy's is barely tolerable, but this location (a busy one due to location for sure) is pretty awful.

Not a good choice.

You're kidding right?  This Au Bon Pain should probably get 1 star due to the vermin infestation.  But anyway - the over priced, high calorie sandwiches & soups are a godsend when it is raining and I am too lazy to leave my office building, but other than that?

I am so over au bon pain.

Ook!  I had a horrible ordeal here - albeit years ago - in the emergency room.

I was left waiting in a triage room for HOURS & HOURS because they could not decide whether or not to admit me.

They eventually decided not to admit me and let me out at about 3 AM in West Philly with no cab fare and I was scared to death.  Thank god a local cop drove me home.


Meanwhile the doctors & nurses there seemed very confused and did not display good judgement in my treatment.  I was in need of care and they failed me.

Very, very disappointing.

Audrey Claire is weird.

I wanted to like it.  I wanted to love it - but it was only "meh".
The homey wood-tabled decor was nice - but the acoustics were awful.  So loud.

The white-aproned staff was kinda snotty - especially when we asked alot of questions - which we always do.

The food was just OK.  The standout being a plate of whole grilled artichokes that we had for an appetizer - but for the 7-8 bucks - I coulda done that myself.

The food is very elemental here - simplistic.  Not Horrible (in fact a 3 or even 4 stars for food) but as a total dining experience?  I probably won't be back.

And its a BYO.  So bring something -
- you'll need it.

Oh - and bring cash - no credit cards.

Whatever.

I just was not thrilled with the food here.  Yes - it's a busy, Asia-inspired, zen ish decor - even the ladies room has been dollied up to the hilt.  (Maybe it's a little over the top, even??)  The food was just not good.

I had an average sushi roll app and an entree so unmemorable that I can't event tell you what it was.

We went for lunch and I will not go back.  There are way better places.

Maybe the drinks (which we did not have at lunch time) are why the high reviews?  The food was pretty lame.

I am so NOT a fan of COsi.  After eating in the in NYC in the early 200's when this chain emerged - it seemed cool at first.  And - if the bread is fresh and hot (before it solidifies into cold cardboard) it actually tastes pretty good.

The hungrier you are the better it'll taste.

Meanwhile - the overpriced sandwich fillings are mediocre at best.
There are better places to waste (I mean spend) my $7 bux.

Sorry.  Not a big fan.

If it's in 30th Street Station and I REALLY need food - I would eat here over McDonalds or Au Bon Pain - but that's really not saying much.

The Doylestown BK has been around for a long, long time - at least 32 years.  (The McDonald's up the road came first, though.)

As BKs go - and I am not a fan - this one is decent.  often tables and restrooms need more cleaning, though.

It's a reliable fast food option - though I loathe the stuff.

I stopped in at Roller's during the Chestnut Hill Festival basically to get away from the street crowds and hopefully, to score a decent lunch.

Not so great.

The service was a bit familial and weird.  2 very nice ladies ran the "front of the house"  the server was nice - the manager (maybe owner?) not so friendly.  She was way more attentive to the couple to my left and the family to my right - but I guess since I was dining solo - maybe I wasn't worth it??

I asked if lunch was being served (it was 2 in the afternoon) but told olnly brunch and breakfast.  So I ordered a Turkey BLT on Le Bus multi grain toast (menu said 5.75 - was eventually charged 6.25) and the nice server lady said, "I'm not sure if we have lettuce.  I'll have to go check."  (I was like, "What?", but did not say anything.)

Turns out they DID have lettuce.  Maybe that's why they charged me more?  But it's a BLT.  The L supposedly stands for LETTUCE.

Oh well.  You can't win 'em all.

Meanwhile, I rested my weary self a while and escaped from the throngs of yuppies and suburbanites, and ate a tasty Turkey BLT.

With Lettuce.

Will I rush back here?  Likely not.

2-3 stars for food.  1-2 for service.

Oh - and bring cash - NO CREDIT CARDS

I am ever-so disappointed with Gennaro's - and just went there again for the first time in years as it never is good.

Well, I was right - my cappucino came out with curdled milk.  Ick.
Fortunately the very kind server, Wendy, brought me another one and took it off the bill.

My close friend eats here ALL the time and loves it, but I just don;t get it.
It's never "quite right" for me here.

Friendly service, old-school digs (they need new carpeting) and a menu to match.

People/Locals love it.  Maybe New Yawk has spoiled me for Delco-Italian.

This starbucks is deceptive.
First of all, parking is horrendous - there's just not enough of it.
Secondly there is hardly any seating - a few bar stools and a few tiny tables for 2.
Thirdly, the retail area - used also to barricade off the drink line area - is too bulky and wide.

This location is deceptive in size - it looks like a big store from the outside but is cramped and crowded inside.

Meanwhile the usual Fourbucks menu items prevail.
Service was fine.

It's just too small.

They do not carry Eukenuba nor California Natural (The only foods my dogs(s) eat, so I can't really come here.   They had a few toys and treats on sale.

Seems more fish/aquarium centric than mammal centric, so if you have fish - this could be a good option for you.  Now that Pet Supplies Plus is going out of business, their business should pick up a bit.

Please consider carrying Eukenuba so I can come here.

I am not an Applebee's fan.  I have been to this one twice though - once I was dragged here by my inlaws - who LOVE chain restaurants.  (I guess they make them feel "safe"),

The food was marginal and the service was, of course, by disinterested teenagers.

Not my idea of a good time.

It's been here for eh ver.
Not much good I can say about McDonald's.

Clearly I'm NOT lovin' it.

Went here for a late lunch yesterday (a recession Monday) and the place (huge dining area) was nearly empty.  My friend insisted on coming here as I likely never would have (Can't deal with Public House aka "the Pube" and knew I would likely not like it here anyhow).

Well, It's a sports bar (big f-in' surprise) - and they brew LOUSY iced tea.
Service was fine (there were 3 waitresses just standing around so the one assigned to us jumped at the chance to do something).

My friend had the Fieldhouse Burger - which he enjoyed, although I snagged one of his good lookin' french fries and OOK - a mouthful of salt.

My fieldhouse salad (dressing on the side, no bacon) was surprisingly 3 star.  If I am ever forced back here I will order it again.

So 2-3 stars it is.  Blasting loud '80's music (Billy Ocean's "Get Outta My Dreams - Get Into My Car" was blaring) and ESPN and ESPN2 on every other flat screen.

It's so not my thang, but OK for what it is.  A MEH sports bar.

Well, this is what we're kinda stuck with - considering that we can't afford to get ALL of our shopping done at Whole Paycheck (aka Whole Foods) or Trader Joe's.  Cleaner than Ackamee and less Ghetto than ShopRite (some may argue this).

SuperFresh is our big-chain grocery store of choice based on location and convenience.  A few of the checkers "K" and "Sophie" are actually nice, and know us and our DD because we come here nearly every Sunday.

The produce can be marginal so you must be careful.  

The deli usually has a line, so we nearly always skip it.
We tend to shop aisle by aisle based on a list and coupons (yes, I am currently both BROKE and anal.).

DH like to get 12 packs of canned sodas when they are on special, and I usually get snack foods (healthy-ish when possible, Orange Juice boxes and yogurt for the l'il one.

We need this SuperFresh - for better or for worse.  It's where we've chosen to shop and although it's not super clean, it's THERE and that's why we're there as well.

Oh, and as mentioned by another yelper - they always play SLAMMIN' classic rock - usually loud enough so I can hear it!  (Pink Floyd, Jethro Tull - amazing!  I love that!)

Stopped in here (cash only) after a production at Arden Theatre.
Our 7 year old said it was awful and the cake batter flavor made her sick.

The heat from the 4 yogurt machines (one was broken) was unbearable and the cashier was more interested in picking up her chinese take-out.

Will not go back.  There are many, many better fro-yo spots in Philly.

I loathe Domino's so 2 stars is pretty darned generous coming from me.
The only reason we got pizza here is because my frugal father in law had a coupon (He normally gets Papa John's - which is still mediocre at best).

This is a teeny-tiny take-out only "kiosk" - small store.
Not for eating in!

Yick.

Absolutely disappointed in a private event held in an upstairs room.
ONE waiter passing tiny fried hors d'ouvres and ONE bartender at a jam packed cash bar.

Not enough staff and not enough food for the crowd of 100 plus.

Nope.  Not very good Sorry - even though it's been around for-eh-ver, the food is just OK.  (Italian "red sauce" fare) and the place needs an overhaul.  I guess what makes it so awful for me is that a spider spun her web down onto my plate while I was eating there.  There was dust and cobwebs in the windowsill and that spider just clinched it for me.

I couldn't even finish my baked ziti.

Won't return.

A tiny, tiny grocery store - but it's got what you need - maybe not at the greatest prices - and for a long while it was all Dublin really had.

Brain-dead clerks & cashiers - but they will smile back if you smile first.

It's a grocery store - and I am glad it's here - but it sure could use an overhaul both physically (clean up the aisles and floors) and customer-service-wise.

The older lady at the deli counter was really nice, though - 4 stars for her.  Darned if I can't remeber her name, though. She sliced up some turkey breast for me and 3 slices of liverwurst for my sweet little pug.

So very disappointed and actually...
SAD.

Yes, I left Ooka tonight feeling sad.

Sad - for the fact that we had food (entrees) so bad that we had to send it back.
Sad - to see my favorite D-town sushi spot be anything other than the wonderful we usually expect.
Sad - to have had to defend my right to consume undercooked meat or seafood products.

Just sad.

Do not order duck breast here.  I did - and asked for medium rare - and that duck had the quack cooked right out of it.

As usual the seared striped bass with foie gras was excellent.

Everything else?  MEH,

So sad to have to give out 2 Meh stars to Ooka.

We pray that when and If we give them another chance that they will redeem themselves.

Sad
Sad
Sad.

i am not a big Macy's shopper - but even for a Macy's this one is lame.
I used to shop at the Wanamaker/Macy's (in Center City) and if there were sales you could get some decent clothing, shoes and kids clothing.

Here in Springfield?  Not so much.
It's hit or miss and I usually miss.
The Calvin Klein dress I wanted was full retail at $134.99 - and I got a very similar one at Century 21 (in Philly) for $69.99 - so, I am not too keen on Macy's these days.

For kids clothes?  Entirely too pricey.

Products?  Great.
Service?  Needs work.

I called and left a voice mail weeks before my daughter's birthday to see about getting a quote for a custom donut order (Their donuts are the best in this area - so good, especially when fresh.)

Unfortunately nobody called me back until the night before the event and I had already purchased donuts elsewhere.

I was getting desperate so I went somewhere else and they won't be as good.

I sure wish they had listened to my voice message sooner.


Will try again and next time I will call multiple times.

A little dirtier than Midtown 2 - but the same basic old-skool diner vibe.
Good for breakfasts and cheap dinners.

It is creepy though - but my 5 year old loves to get one pancake and one scrambled egg here.

I agree with McThrill - why soooooo many Dunkins so close to each other?  (And amazingly - even in this economy - long lines at each during the morning rush.  (There's your answer.)

I trek through here very often - although not nearly as often as when I commuted in on my beloved-behated R5 (but that's for another review - see SEPTA).  I disagree about the juicebar.  It is not great - the one in the Comcast Center is way better (Sook Hee's Squeeze Juice Bar).

I really liked Pasero's Coffee before they were taken over by Juan Valdez - byt still, it beats Charbucks (Fourbucks - whatever).

Meanwhile, it's a necessary evil.

Just awful.
Our server Lara was nice enough - and thankfully the manager (who looked about 18 years old) comped my in-edlible over-cooked salmon. Dry.  Awful.  (And I asked them to cook it less than they usually do - which is Medium-well).

Thankfully it was very inexpensive (we got the 2 for $25 lunch deal - one app, 2 entrees, dessert).

The food was just not good - and the service was so slow.
Like watching paint dry.  45 minutes to get the app, 20 more for entree.

Will NOT return.

The spotted hog is one of the lower-priced options within the confines of Peddler's Village.  It is certainly way cheaper than Earl's Prime or the Cock 'n Bull which are the more high-end PV establishments.  You can take the kiddies here and refresh yourself on mediocre food and sandwiches before another round of shopping.

Avoid during the holidays.  It gets mobbed.

The best place to sit in the Sugarhouse casino.  A simple bar with a TV showing "the" game.  Go when it's not crowded.

But truthfully, Sugarhouse is just not my bag, baby.

Honestly?  Were it not for proximity - I would NEVER here  - I'd sooner go to AC or even Bethlehem, PA.

Philly fought long & hard to get a casino - and THIS is what they get?

Sorry - Unimpressed.

I honestly am at a loss for words.

I went to Franco's tonight as part of a VERY large group (35-40 ladies) with a set menu (that sounded great on paper.).

Franco's had a lovely decor (once we managed to find a spot in the jam-packed lot) and the hostess (a pretty young Asian woman) was friendly and professional.

Our group had a semi private portion of the restaurant.
We began arriving for cocktails at 5:30 (dinner was to start at 7) at the packed bar.

By 7:20 dinner had still not started.
At 7;30 the first few salads (all of us were to have the SAME - BORING - mixed greens with 2 grape tomatoes and barely a whisper of balsamic vinaigrette.) started to arrive.

By 8:00 (we were so hungry we devored the baskets of Uber-SALTY focaccia (UCK) and decent Italian bread), they came to take our orders (IMO they shoulda done that much sooner.)

My entree (eggplant parm) arrived at 8:45.
I ate 2 bites (it was just OK) and had ot wrapped to go.

Meanwhile the 4 entrees we have to choose from were Cheese ravioli Marinara, Eggplant Parm with Penne, Tilapia with Capers or Salmion with Olive Oil & Herbs.

Our tablemates had the tilapia and claimed it was under seasoned (perhaps the over-seasoned foccacia would have helped)?

Meanwhile the sweet young boys (er, men??) bussing and serving were clearly way, way, way overwhelmed by our party.

Badly handled.
Mediocre Food.

I had high hopes for this place, but I am in no hurry to rush back.  (Menu prices for the entrees our group had were from $14.75 - $19.75).

I did not get a chance to try the profiteroles for dessert.  The service simply started too late and ran too long.

Eh.  Meh.

Whatever.  It's OK.  I prefer the pits at Aya's or Mama's.
It is a nice alternative to fast food though.

Maybe I should give them 3 stars?

They are a solid 2 and a half.
Staff are CLUELESS. Prices are low (which is helpful.)
It's relatively clean.

I just wasn't BLOWN away by my chicken pita sandwich.

I have nicknamed Walmart, "Wal-nuts" because the people who shop there are truly on the brink of insanity.  Shopping only based on price.

Yes, it's cheap - but also chaotic, crowded (the check out experience is not pleasant) and for a few bucks more, I'd rather go elsewhere.

That said, Walnuts has saved my a$$ on numerous occasions when I needed groceries (This one is a a SUPER-Walnuts - with groceries, dairy and produce) or household supplies.

Yup - it's cheap.

Be patient.  This ain't no party.
This ain't no disco
This ain't no foolin' around...

Awful excuse for a strip mall.
Run-down K mart and a few struggling stores.

YUCK.

I was dragged here yet again, and the food and service were decidedly sucky.  (Sorry "Amanda" - sweet yet clueless high-school aged server).

Mistake 1.  (Our bad) Come on a Saturday night at 6:30
Mistake 2.  Patiently wait for table with5 year old
Mistake 3. Ask for "a few minutes" when said server asks "Ready to order?"

My kid nearly had a melt down while waiting for her $3.99 Kraft Mac 'n Cheese and my $9.99 burger - asked for medium- was charred and tasteless.

Yick.

Hope my inlaws enjoyed the teeny tiny overly salted steaks.
If it were not for their generosity, I would never, ever come here.  (They paid, they picked. And, yes, I am grateful to them - but please - there are so many better places to go.)

DH & DD, a friend and I were trapped in the convention center during a freezing cold Flower Show and since Hard Rock was packed (35 minute wait) we snagged a table at the Field-Hole.  

Lunch was unsurprisingly unremarkable. My Cobb Salad (regularly $14 with chicken) was jacked up to $20 when I asked to sub steak.  4 oz maybe of just OK steak.  5 cherry tomatoes cut in half, a few chunks of avocado and some over-cooked bacon chunks/chips.  I have had better and worse Cobbs.

The best part?  Our server Dana was an over-worked sweetheart.  She did her very best in a dining room packed with kids and families weary from the Flower Show.

Prices are a bit too high for the sub-par "formula" bar food that is served.

No Bueno.
My father's crab cake platter (which sounded great on the menu - served with a mushroom risotto and asparagus) was nearly all filler.

Yes, this is a diner - but he was sorely disappointed.

Won't be back.

The flowers my friend sent me for the holidays were awful - nearly dead upon arrival, so they sent a replacement which was much fresher.

Not a great florist.

It seems like they should have decent food here - but alas, no.  Service is pretty disinterested, and the prices are more than the quality demands.

I did get a nice side of steamed broccoli in lieu of the fries - so that was good.

I don't come here unless co-workers force me to.

Wendy's is never our top choice for dining - but el kiddo wanted something chicken-y so we stopped in (dine in) and she got her "value menu" chicken sandwich with lettuce, mayo and bacon added (30 cents extra).

Hubby got a few burgers that he ate sans bun.

We all got 99 cent frosties.

I tried the "new" bacon cheeseburger on a pretzel bun.  What a horrific waste of calories.  Bun was overbaked (dark brown and nearly black).  Loaded with both sliced cheese and a nasty fake-cheese whiz-like sauce.

Never again.

Batherroms were moderately clean.
Service was poor - order was worng the first time  but corrected the second.

Please was dead empty at 5:30 PM on a Sunday.
Drive through had a line though.

Creepy!

Just OK today.  I had not been here in quite some time and while the hot foods/cooked foods seem to have expanded the sushi was just not fresh.  I ordered a side order of ("new") grilled tofu - at $4.50 which was tasty and safe to eat.

The $10.95 (pricey) Valentine roll had very questional salmon inside.  So questionable that I still don;t know if it was supposed to be raw fresh salmon, smoked salmon or just old, nasty salmon.

Very disappointed - and I spent over $16 on a carry out lunch.
I will not be back in a hurry, if ever.

I am not a Cosi fan but I was genuinely STARVING one morning and popped in here for a cup of soup - which came with apiece of their"Cosi bread".

Inarticulate, disinterested staff and watery "Lobster & Butternut Squash" soup which had little to zero lobster and an oddly fishy note.

I won't be ordering THAT ever again.

Changed location and owners, and so pricey - and not worth it anymore.

I am sad.
I liked the old Gross'.

RIP.

This bar has not changed in the last 25 years.
Mostly biker-type regulars from Q-town or Souderton and a few D-town long-timers.
Nice people in a dark and smoky bar (Hooray - you actually still smoke here).

Cheap drinks and easy access to the rest of town.

Not my thing - but OK in a pinch. 
The bartender Susie is a doll.

I agree with Eveline - and I too am writing this review based on grease-laden memories of my post-collegiate Chinese Truck experience.

I don't understand the love.  Food is (as said before) full of oil, onions and MSG.

Yech!

Oh - but it's really, really cheap.

Their donation policies seem more restrictive and inconvenient (when and what they will accept donations) than other SA or Goodwill stores.  I come here mostly to donate items - not to purchase.  Glad they are here, though.

Update:  The building was destroyed in a tragic Collapse in June 2013 - killing 6 people and injurying many more.  So sad.

Walked in, walked out.
Crowded, poor service, mediocre food.

But it is convenient when you just NEED to sit down in RTM.

Asked for water several times.
Tripped over strollers.

Not a fun experience at all. (Which is a shame because I LOVE Jack McDavid - not sure if he still has a hand in this biz,)

I have been here twice - the first time was when they first opened and it was great - maybe 4 stars.  We had $1.70 sliders and fabulous ginger & pineapple cocktails.  We sat on a sofa in a corner of the bar and had great service.

A few months later we went back - this time for Center City Sips.  The place was PACKED, the menu (food and drinks) had changed and the service was just awful. A 1 star experience.

Thus, I am giving them 2 stars and I will not return.

2 stars on a bad day - 3 on a good day?
This one is way better than the FILTHY friendly's down 611.

Meanwhile, my 4 year old daughter simply MUST have the cone-head sundae, so my DH and I gave in and had lunch here.

It wasn't AWFUL - but it was very slow service and mediocre food that is really not good for you.  (Fried chicken fingers & burgers.)

Not a fan.  Sorry.

I absolutely agree with Zach.  I enter or exit this station several times per week and you have to use the Vine Street side.

Plus - what is the point of that token booth attendant if you can't buy tokens?  There is a change machine - but only for change - no tokens.

Meanwhile I am glad to live so close to a BSL stop, but some changes need to be made.

Absolute mediocrity - but at a very cheap price. (A typical case of "you get what you pay for".)

My 7 year old and I stopped in - for a polish change ($5) and a manicure for me ($10).  Since she got fidgety we both ended up getting polish changes.  Mine chipped right away - even though I coulda sworn she used CND basecoat (which is a great product).  DD chipped hers too - but that was her fault.

Not very clean (I would NOT get a $20 pedi here EVER.).

Not coming back.

Cheap and would do in a desparate pinch.

Worse and worse every time we come.
The firt time we had a great 4 star experience.  This last time?  Not so much.

And do NOT get take out here.  No beverages to go (other than sugar-laden Mexican Sodas).  No Diet Coke.  No take out cups.  Bottled water (IF they have it) is $2.25 per bottle.

Plus they got my order wrong - and I called 45 minutes before I needed it.

They are clearly not well equipped for take out.

2 to 2.5 stars at best.

What a disappointment.
A close friend and I had been planning dinner here for over 2 months.
We finally got to go and the food just isn't up to par (or the high prices - $22 - $45 for entrees!).

We started our meal with delicious fresh bread and garlic-infused oil.  (That and the after-dinner coffee were the best bites of the night!)

I love a good caprese salad and was thrilled when "Fresh tomato and buffalo mozz" was a featured special ($12).  My friend and I split it - and the tomatoes were HARD - deli-quality slicing tomatoes.  This - in the middle of August when tomatoes are plentiful - is a sacrilege!  Also - who serves this over iceberg lettuce?  ICEBERG?  On a Caprese?

Blah!!!

Our server Leo tried to please us - but the entrees fell flat.
My entree was OK (albeit very over-salted) - al dente linguine with about a doze steamed littlenecks in a garlicky, salt-bath of oil.

My friends "veal saute" was a joke.  While the veal was tender, the sauce was a bland concoction of greasy-oily floury blandness.  It was supposed to be a "light white wine sauce" and no wine or flavor was detectable.

We skipped dessert and had 2 very nice cups of $3 coffee.

I would not go back here.
"Founded in 1990" - looks like they have not renovated since 2002.

FAIL!

Such a shame.

I love CVS - but this branch is RIDICULOUS.  The line is always long, clerks unfriendly (better at the pharmacy - but the "front line" is atrocious.   I consider it a neccessary evil, as this is the only CVS near my office. (ANd they do have everything I need - usually higher priced  but, Oh well.

Not sure why - but the Philly outpost of crumbs seems a bit...
...Stale?  Maybe it's because nothing is baked on premises.  It's all trucked in from NYC.

Walked in - excited to see a Crumbs (like those in NYC) here in Philly.
The large cupcakes are way too much for one person - and many have an overload of toppings. I tend to stay with the "Squiggle" or simpler versions.

Meanwhile - the cake pops on display (push up pops?) looks so artificially colored it was off putting.  Stick with the mini cupcakes.  A better size and price point.

And the front of the store is EMPTY - you have to walk in and THEN you see the counter.

A plus? You can get your favorite over-priced fourbucks aka Starbucks latte or mocha.

OK, 3 strikes and I'm OUT!  Outta Tavern 17.

The weird (slightly older, short, surly) bartender treated me very strangely - kinda like I have a stick up my a$$ or something.  Anyhow - I hemmed and hawed a bit as to whether or not to even order alcohol (And bartenders don;t care for this), and ordered an iced tea.  (No, not a long island one - a regular brewed one).  It was nearly BLACK.  Overbrewed.

He nearly went ballaistic when I dained to ask for Splenda and mocked me a bit.  I guess I deserved it.

I also ordered two of the $1 sliders.  For a buck - they are well worth it and 2 (or 3 if I am absolutely starving) is perfect.

The best part of the night?  Tish (Leticia) the lovely hostess who got us extra chairs and gave me the ladies room key twice (I pee freely.),  Note ladies:  It's a long trek to the ladies room.  Also note: it's been recently renovated (The loo, that is).

All in all, had my friends not picked this place (I swear, twas not my idea) I woulda never set foot in the joint.

Sorry, Mickey or Mikey or whatever your name is...

Tish - you rock.  You deserve a BIG raise!

Why on earth suburbanites PACK this place (with kids, also) is beyond me.
We came here when we were out of other ideas and the wait at Grand Rodeo was 45 minutes.

Well, the wait here was 45 minutes also (even though we were told it'd be 20-25 minutes.)

Literally THRONGS of people.

Avoid on a Saturday night at all cost.
Mediocrity served in enormous portions with a side of bovine growth hormone.

I'll pass.

But I bet somebody will drag me back here.

Meh - 1.5 stars.  food was 2 and service was 1 or zero.  My husband asked them to cut our kid's slice into squares and they could not figure out how to do this.  Odd.  We cut it ourselves.

I had a chicken cheese steak.
It was pretty awful.

We won't go again.

I'm sorry but the food here truly sucks.
We came as part of a large group party (I would never dine here of my own accord - I men, El Limon, Chiang Mai and Black Fish are all on the same street!) and they provided a cash bar (luckily sodas were free) and 5 hot appetizers in chafing dishes.

Thank g-d for the vegetable tray - it was fresh and fine.

Wings?  Mediocre - kinda dry.
Mozz. Sticks - cold
Scaliop pieces (or was in a shrimp, or a piece of cheap fish) wrapped in flabby bacon - ICKY.
Fried Gyoza/Potstickers - clearly frozen but at least edible.
And one other item I forget - as I clearly did not eat it.

Not a fan.

Gross food.
Dana R.'s review is accurate.  Sarku has never been a favorite of mine - too oily and carb-heavy.  Chicken is just OK - very greasy.

Pretty Mediocre.  The family stopped in here while house hunting in this area. Clean but GRAY and cafeteria-like dining area.  DD had a meatball sub (my meatballs are better - these were bready and tasteless), DH had a cheesesteak which he hated and I actually like my (Kronos pre-packed, obviously frozen) Gyro sandwich on Pita.

The gents behind the counter were friendly and very nice.
I was leaning toward 3 stars until I tasted DD's sub.  Blech!

Bathroom was clean and decent.

The place needs a facelift for the dining room and a re-vamp of the "classic" Greek-owned Pizzeria menu.

I wish I could have liked it better - but we will NOT be back.

They opened a brand-new ALDI on 352 near the Wawa, where the old Giant (now across 352) used to be.

I had a pretty crappy first experience, and I was excited to try Aldi as friends have said it is "really cheap".  Well, sometimes you get what you pay for...

In this case my experience sucked before it even began.  In the parking lot.  I walked up to get a cart and you need to put a Quarter in to release a cart.  Feh.  I had no quarters.  So I figured I'd "wing it" and only buy what I could carry (which was about  5 items). There are no shopping baskets inside the store, either.  What is this? Grays Ferry?

So I browse and I shop, and yes the prices are super low, but - BUT - no-name brands or brands I have NEVER heard of and no sourcing info.  (Fresh grated Parmesan-type cheese for $1.99 - distributed by ALDI in IL but WHERE is it from?  US?  Italy (no way)?)  Too scared to buy meat here. Bought my kid a cookies & cream type candy bar from Germany (interesting).

I approach the checkout line and there is ONE lady working (everyone else has scattered) who desperately wants to go on break.  The lady ahead of me is being served and I remarked (out loud - my BIG mistake) Oh, they have no plastic bags?  And the eco-conscious lady ahead of me gave me a HUGE earful about how all stores should do this and how "You need to bring your own bags" and how it's better for the environment and on and on.  And, honestly, she is correct - but her snappy, bitchy-toned delivery needed much improvement.

She left and I paid for my $11 worth of stuff (which would have cost about $15 at Giant) and hand-carried it out to my car.  (Admittedly, I looked around in the parking lot to make sure that lady was gone.  She was really pissed off for some reason.) 

Next time I will remember to bring a quarter and my own bags.

If there is a next time.

I am in absolutely no rush to ever return to ALDI.

2 stars is plenty generous for this chain of BLAH seafood (all pre-frozen) and bisquick (Cheddar Bay) biscuits.

It's the Olive Garden of the sea.

And my brother in law and his wife both worked here when they were just out of high school, met and fewll in love here and now are married.  Best thing to come out of a Red Lobster in my opinion.  Certainly the food is not "gourmet".

Picked up my stuff and paid $85 by personal check (Whatevah!).
Lady is very nice and clothing seems to be OK and does not smell bad.

Still, I will NOT go back here.

So, against my better judgement, I walked in on a whim to see if I could get a (cheap) blow-out.
I had a special event on a Saturday night and - by some miracle - the place was dead-empty.

Danielle (a 22 year-ish, fresh outta High School stylist) did a simple and decent blow-out (not flat itron - as that would have added $15 - Feh.)

So my TOTAL was $15 - with tip was $21.  

Still not mad about this place, but at least the high staff turnover has brought in some better people.

Wait 6 months - they'll all change again.  (The owner of this franchise owns OVER 50 LOCATIONS.  Wow!)

Globs of hair by front door - needed sweeping.

I would NEVER get color, highlights or any complex chemical service here.
It's basically a training ground for stylists right outta school.
Lots of MEN and kids come here in search of a cheap cut.

You get what u pay for!

Ok, it does suck here - but what choice do we have?

I am a mother of one of those crying toddlers - and this is where we go to see such classics as Madagascar and Wall-e.

Oh, G-d.  Make it stop.

This ShopRite is pretty nasty.  If you happen to come on a weekday, just after the shelves (and produce) are stocked - it's passable, but the weekends are hellish chaos.

Customer Service?  Slim to none.

At least the prices are lower than Whole Foods (as is quality) and sometimes lower then SuperFresh.

Oh - and when we shop with our child we always disinfect the nasty shopping carts.  Eeew.  Sticky & Gross.  I really loathe taking her there.  the slow moving lines make her antsy.

Not a fave for me, but - since our choices for grocery shopping are so limited in Philly (Where ARE you Fresh Direct?  PeaPod?), I am glad they exist.

I just don't dig the Coffee Bar.  It's OK in a pinch - but ING Direct has bette, cheaper coffee.  This place is EXPENSIVE - you are paying hotel prices.

The decor is still nicer - nicer than back in the Capriccio Days - and it ain't Starbucks. (Which is a good thing in my book.)

Nice place to sit & rest   - I usually buy one cheap beverage and nurse it a while.

We ate here on July 2 - during the BIG crowds of the 4th of July weekend pre-fireworks mayhem.  We needed a place to kill 2 hours and eat.

I went with DH & 6 year old DD who was pretty well behaved, considering.
We each ordered the $24.95 3 course pre-fixe and DD picked off my plate - Shrimp risotto (which was awful - gloppy and in some sort of weird "brown gravy")  Odd.

The soup - Clam Chowder - was watery and just Meh.

Service was bad, too.  The hostess is a doll and our server was fine - but the bus lady took alot of our stuff away before we were ready (I got up to use the ladies room and when I got back my napkin and water glass were gone. - I mean, who clears away the WATER glasses - you wait until the meal is over for that.)

Anyhow, at least they waived the $5 plate sharing charge.

Would NOT rush back - even though I still have dreams about the pierogies (only at lunchtime).

Friends don't let friends drink fourbucks.  This particular location is crowded fduring the AM rush especially.

I also call it CHARbucks as the coffee drinks usually are roastde too dark for me.  The espresso drinks are passable - but be careful as they are loaded with sugar and often with fat if you get them made with whole milk.

Not a big fan of Starbucks in general.  We grind and brew our own at home using peregrine coffee beans for a fraction of the price.

I am vacillating bewteen a 2 and a 3.
Grabbed a quick sushi (4 pieces of nigiri and 1/2 a california roll) and it was $12.00 and change after tax.  Yikes.

The Salmon was fine - but the tuna tasted a bit old.
Mall Sushi.  Serves me right, I should know better.

I will not be back in a hurry and if I return I will try the "cooked" food instead.

The hot food looked OK but there were alot of fried items.

Quick cheap and good for college students.

Let me just say that the last time I was in Beijing was 1995.  Really.
I am amazed it's still here.  It's becoming a Penn institution.

Back in the day I'd get the lunch specials. CHicken & Brocolli or Steamed Shrimp & Veggies.  More than a few orders of thick doughy dumplings, too.  (Not the greatest by any stretch.)

Quick and cheap.

Not superb - but a good value.

Meh.  It's really small - and has a coffee bar, a bar and ONE (lame menu) burger-bar food based restaurant.

Lots of slots and a few table games.

Not my bag, baby.

Honestly?  Were it not for proximity - I would NEVER come to Sugarhouse - I'd sooner go to AC or even Bethlehem, PA.

Philly fought long & hard to get a casino - and THIS is what they get?

Sorry - Unimpressed.

Yuck.  I really loather chain restaurants and Chili's is no exception.  The one nice this about this Chili's is it's proximity to the Penn Campus and the universally cheap and greasy burgers and other fried foods are the same at any Chili's nation wide.

It's kinda dirty in here - and the place is run by teenagers.

I guess it beats TGI Friday's - but not by much.

Yes, Tom A.  everyone IS right.  Total mediocrity and a neccessary evil.  Philadelphia has a piss-poor number of grocery stores and supermarkets.  The Superfresh kinda sucks, the Pathmark is ghetto and this ACME is barely passable.

We come here when we don't wanna deal with Superfresh's picked-over produce.  And then we'll come here and it'll be just as bad with a  picked over dairy case.

CHECK YOUR FRESHNESS DATES on meat and dairy products especially.  We found yogurt that was 2 weeks past it's date.  (We told the manager who promptly pulled it off the shelves.)

Be careful.

Like Superfresh and Pathmark (which are also filthy), ACME could use a good cleaning.  The floors are just nasty.

Stopped in once while in 30th Street - looked around and left.
I'm not a big fan of Au Bon Pain.

I had a mediocre at best experience here.  I would NEVER get a pedicure here.  I came here once to try it out (on just a mani) and I won't return.  First of all, it's very cramped in there - and if you don't have an appointment, you could be waiting a while.

The techs are mostly Asian and don't speak alot of english.  The lady I had seemed very rushed to get me done and get onto the next client.

They do not offer massage.

Whatever.  El-Cheapo rushed, basic mani.

I won't be back.

This City Nails is not owned by the same people as the $hi*ty  nails on South 17th Street.

This place is marginally cleaner and better run - but it's still a far cry from clean, sleek & luxurious.

What it is is cheap and, for some, convenient.

The ladies will shout "Peek-collah" at you when you arrive.  I usually bring my own base & top coats as I do not care for the no-name  base coat they use.

I would NEVER get a pedi here.  I am uber-picky about pedis and only get them at Spa Elysium from Cheryl Lee.

Uh Oh.  I should have trusted my instincts.
I dropped off $85 worth of clothes today and she told me it would be cash or check only and I was like "What???" Plus it smelled just AWFUL in there.  (She wanted to charge me $13 for each dress - but I talked her down to $11 which is what my other cleaner charges.)

So against my better judgement I left my clothing there.  They are due to come back Thursday.  I pray they smell OK.

Wish I would have read these reviews first.

Lady was very nice but also pushy and I felt guilty not leaving my stuff there even though many red flags went up even before the whole "no credit card" thing.  It just smells HORRID in there.

I hope I do not get burned,
I have a sneaking suspicion i may nee to take the clothes somewhere else and re-do them.

Fingers crossed.
If I can please get my stuff back unscathed I highly doubt i will ever fall for this again.

Um - for this part of Philly it's not so bad - but compared to a "normal" Pier one?  It's kinda hectic in here at times and the displays get knocked around and messed up due to the crowds of Phjilly folk that rush on through.

A decent place for home decor, furniture and table ware. (Candles on sale are a good deal.)

Not a big fan though, due to the disheveled feeling of the store.

Hit or miss - but when you hit, you hit big.
You gotta be prepared to wade through the scattered, disorganished racks and try things on,

Cheap? Yes.
Pain in the neck to shop here? Yes.

There are better and worse Marshall's locations.  This one is just MEH.
Avoid during December and 1st week of Jan (holiday lines are long and sooooo not worth it).

What can I say anout Dunkin Donuts - really?  Some people love the coffee here - I think it's just OK.  (I mean, once you've been spoiled by Peregrine it's hard to turn back)  It's better than Charbucks - and cheaper.

I have also tried the regular and white hot chocolates.  They are mixed from powders and come shooting out of a dispenser.  The white hot chocolate is like drinking a cup of sugary fat.  It's sickening.  The "regular" hot cocoa - while also sugar laden is at least drinkable.

The donuts are not baked on premises and thus sometimes are not too fresh.  

I guess I'm just not a DD gal. America may run on Dunkin - but I'll be running away.  Oh - my 5 year old LOVES DD - especially munchkins - but she's 5 and will eat anything sweet.

kKnda grungy - but they DO play classic rock tunes while you shop.
I get a few staples/non perishable items here and then hit whole foods for produce and hormone-reduced dairy.

In the old days when 94.1 WYSP was classic rock (with Andre Gardner and Debbie Calton) I loved it.  Now all the good Classic rock is at WMGK 102.9 (Oddly enough that was the lite hits - valium rock channel back in the day.)

Also John DiBella (from WMMR is now on WMJK in the mornings - and is still as wacky as ever.  But I digresss..

Anyhow, now 94.1 plays alot of commercials.  In between the have a good mix of harder and softer well-known and lesser known rock and urban-rock hits.

Better than it used to be - and schedules are still often late/behind.
Take the train if you can afford it - Greyhound is just awful.

Septa or Amtrak are much better than the buses.

Surly service from underpaid workers.

Started out GREAt and was all down hill from there.

In the fall of 2007 I went to Mission grill and had the most AMAZING lunch.  A delicious salad with shrimp & crab - fresh avocado and mango.  Cilantro-lime-yumminess for dressing and cute little tortilla strips.  Four to Five star food and great service.
 
It was so good - and the place so new (I had yet to realize that "The pube" - public house - owns it.) that I even RECOMMENDED others at my firm to try it.

I had another good lunch.  And another.

And then my (now husband, then) fiance and I went for New Years eve.
And it was about 3 stars.  (Now, I know, I know, NYE is a bad night on which to judge a rest-o - but wait...)

In February 2008 I retuned for another lunch - and lo... the menu was completely changed.

No more salad.
No more empananas
Mediocre gazpacho.

And service has gone waaaaaaaaay downhill.

I also came for a happy hour in April 2008 where I had a "$5. Margarita" that tasted like lime pixie dust.

Sorry.

The place has peaked and is now on the way down.
I hope they'll turn it around.

OMG Romano's is just AWFUL.  Yes, it's a chain.  Yes they serve sub-par bitter (often rancid) carafes of inedible olive oil on every table.  Yes, the food is loaded with salt.

No, this is not what Italian-American food should be.  No, I do NOT want to ever come back here.

Customer service is slacking - especially if you order inside the store (They are all busy dealing with the drive thru).  You need better counter people - some of the old crew has left and you can tell.

Step it up, Media, Starbucks.  We need you!

Meh.  Just ok, but my elderly parents love it here. Inexpensive and "safe" breakfast, lunch and dinner, too.

Avoid the fish (salmon, talapia), ick.

Stick to eggs and pancakes

This place is way passed its prime.  It's been around since the late eighties - and back then was one of the only "Adult" shops around.  Frankly, I can't believe they are still here.  

But yes, you can stock up on toys and party favors here - and other "naughty bits".

And yes, it is in the BASEMENT - and theirs just something psychological for me about going DOWN into a sex shop.  (Ba dum, bump!)

Pretty darned awful.  We were cajoled into coming here by our 5 year old after dining at the illiustrious IHOP next door.  After purchasing $10.00 worth of tokens it was off to the filthy, sticky, germ-laden "rides" and games. 

I could feel myself contracting a rhinovirus by the minute.
Oh - and when I put a token in the mini carousel (my kid was the only one on it) about 5 little kids sensed "free ride" and pushed their way on board freaking her (and me) right out.  NO PARENTAL supervision of these kids.  Ugh.

We also played some "ski-ball" and then the little one fed the tickets into the "ticket muncher" to have them counted which took about 23 minutes.  The 103 tickets got her a cheap plastic ring, stickers and some small plastic object that I still don;t know what it is.

And we still have about 8 tokens left over for next time.

Next time?

Oh dear g-d please don;t make me come back here.

We were greeted in a very friendly manner and offered free chocolates.  After being seated though, we just had to leave.  This is not an appropriate venue for a business lunch.  Loud, distracting decor and a predominantly chocolate menu made it hard to choose from the over priced snacky-type lunch menu.

Save this place for a date or (if you're rich) bring the kids who are sure to be entertained here.

This place will fail if they don;t offer some sensible lunch choices (Salads were $13.95) or lunch specials.
